thread.title: Portrait perfect: Art workshops in the Caribbean
thread.title_full: Portrait perfect: Art workshops in the Caribbean

title: Portrait perfect: Art workshops in the Caribbean
text:
Noted Vermont-based painter Susan Abbott has been conducting workshops in the Bahamas for six years. Susan Abbott Fullscreen Abbott's “Bahamas Winter Retreat” is a week-long workshop held February 3 – 8, 2016 at the Hummingbird Art Centre in Hope Town, on Elbow Cay. Susan Abbott Fullscreen The Bahamas' Hummingbird Art Centre has a workshop space that includes a studio for indoor classes. Susan Abbott Fullscreen Abbott’s students have two painting sessions a day working directly from island motifs, which include sun-splashed harbor views, street scenes, and the island’s Caribbean architecture. Susan Abbott Fullscreen Award-winning sculptor Nilda Comas divides her time between Fort Lauderdale and Pietrasanta, Italy, while still finding time to conduct regularly scheduled workshops in San Juan, Puerto Rico, where she was born. Nilda Comas Fullscreen Nilda Comas' five-day “Living Among the Artists Workshop” is conducted in the Gallery Inn, a 300-year old colonial building in the heart of Old San Juan. Nilda Comas Fullscreen Workshop participants in Comas' classes have a choice between painting and sculpting. Nilda Comas Fullscreen “We’ll also help students pack their sculptures for the trip home,” said Comas. “I bring clay sculptures back and forth from Italy all the time in my carry on.” Nilda Comas Fullscreen In addition to lessons in art, Comas is big on encouraging students to dive into the culture of Puerto Rico, sample the local cuisine, and tour San Juan’s historical attractions. Nilda Comas Fullscreen At Good Hope Pottery & Gallery in Jamaica, the husband and wife team of David and Sheila Pinto offer weekly classes that meld pottery and yoga. David Pinto Fullscreen The session starts at 9 a.m. with a one hour yoga class and then continues with a 10 a.m. to noon pottery class. Students can learn how to create pottery on the wheel, or hand-build their creations. David Pinto Fullscreen “We welcome participants at every experience level, to help shape their journey in art and also add a dimension of local energy,” said Pinto. David Pinto Fullscreen Good Hope Pottery & Gallery often features visiting artists. Here, Potter Doug Casebeer throwing in Good Hope Pottery studio. David Pinto Fullscreen Visiting artist Chris Gustin demonstrating for a group of school children. David Pinto Fullscreen The colorful island of Curacao is where artists will find Nena Sanchez’ “Paint to Relax” workshop. Nena Sanchez Fullscreen Sanchez's three-hour workshop is held in Jan Kok, an 18th century plantation house full of Dutch Caribbean ambience. Nena Sanchez Fullscreen “Most people do not realize that painting can also be a great anti-depression and anti-loneliness remedy,” said Sanchez. Nena Sanchez Fullscreen “You do not need to know how to draw a line; you just need the desire to want to paint and to relax. The rest comes easy,” Sanchez says. Nena Sanchez Fullscreen Sanchez's workshop session concentrates on painting with acrylics and includes all materials: paper, acrylic paint, brushes, and easel. Nena Sanchez Fullscreen Sanchez suggests 30 + as the ideal age for participants. Nena Sanchez Fullscreen If you are lacking in inspiration, take a turn around Sanchez's colorful outdoor gallery. Nena Sanchez The Bahamas' Hummingbird Art Centre has a workshop space that includes a studio for indoor classes. (Photo: Susan Abbott)
7 CONNECT 16 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE It’s a fact of life that most artists have to juggle their creative life with the harsh reality of paying the bills. This means they struggle to balance vocation and avocation. When vacation time finally arrives, artists need to relax as much as anybody. But they also have a lot of pent up desire to paint and sculpt. One way they can satisfy both needs is by enrolling in an island art workshop during their vacation. Workshops such as these are usually held in an artist’s studio, and typically range from a full week to a single afternoon session.
There’s one essential tip for a great workshop experience: Bring the proper attitude. It’s not a competition. Laughter, a light touch, and the Caribbean are a good mix. Artists should do their best to leave perfectionism behind, at least during the span of the workshop.
The Bahamas | Susan Abbott
Noted Vermont-based painter Susan Abbott has been conducting workshops in the Bahamas for six years. Her “Bahamas Winter Retreat” is a week-long workshop held February 3 – 8, 2016 at the Hummingbird Art Centre in Hope Town, on Elbow Cay. The center has a workshop space that includes a studio for indoor classes.
“My classes in the Bahamas focus on landscape painting in oil or watercolor,” said Abbott. “I suggest to students that they concentrate more on process than product while on Elbow Cay. In other words, think more about trying new things, experimenting with composition, and absorbing the light and color of the island – take the pressure off themselves to leave the workshop with finished paintings.”
Abbott’s students have two painting sessions a day working directly from island motifs, which include sun-splashed harbor views, street scenes, and the island’s Caribbean architecture. There’s also time set aside for critiques, lessons in composition and color, and slide lectures on the history of landscape painting, with a focus on techniques used. Susan Abbott can be reached at sa@susanabbott.com.
Puerto Rico | Nilda Comas
Nilda Comas' five-day “Living Among the Artists Workshop” is conducted in the Gallery Inn, a 300-year old colonial building in the heart of Old San Juan. (Photo: Nilda Comas)
Award-winning sculptor Nilda Comas divides her time between Fort Lauderdale and Pietrasanta, Italy, while still finding time to conduct regularly scheduled workshops in San Juan, Puerto Rico, where she was born. Her five-day “Living Among the Artists Workshop” is conducted in the Gallery Inn, a 300-year old colonial building in the heart of Old San Juan. Workshop participants have a choice between painting and sculpting. While supplies are provided, Comas noted that students may want to bring their own favorite supplies with them.
“We’ll also help students pack their sculptures for the trip home,” said Comas. “I bring clay sculptures back and forth from Italy all the time in my carry on.”
In addition to lessons in art, Comas is big on encouraging students to dive into the culture of Puerto Rico, sample the local cuisine, and tour San Juan’s historical attractions. She even arranges a tango demonstration free of charge, with students having the option to add a few tango lessons to their San Juan sojourn. Contact Nilda Comas at nildamcomas@yahoo.com
Jamaica | David Pinto
At Good Hope Pottery & Gallery in Jamaica, the husband and wife team of David and Sheila Pinto offer weekly classes that meld pottery and yoga. (Photo: David Pinto)
A location itself can be inspiring, which is the case with Good Hope Pottery & Gallery. The pottery studio is located on the grounds of the historic Good Hope Estate in Jamaica, surrounded by thick stands of bamboo and partially restored 17th century buildings. The husband and wife team of David and Sheila Pinto offer weekly classes that meld pottery and yoga.
“We welcome participants at every experience level, to help shape their journey in art and also add a dimension of local energy,” said Pinto. “We are in Jamaica, up in this magical old sugar plantation property, where in addition to making pottery, we celebrate local food and culture.”
The session starts at 9 a.m. with a one hour yoga class and then continues with a 10 a.m. to noon pottery class. Students can learn how to create pottery on the wheel, or hand-build their creations. If they have a head of steam going, inspired students can continue to work on their own until 2 p.m. Workshop costs include instruction, clay, glazing, firing, studio and tools. There’s also the option to sign up for a single day of pottery making. David and Sheila Pinto can be contacted at jamaicaclay@gmail.com.
Curacao | Nena Sanchez
Sanchez's workshop session concentrates on painting with acrylics and includes all materials: paper, acrylic paint, brushes, and easel. (Photo: Nena Sanchez)
The colorful island of Curacao is where artists will find Nena Sanchez’ “Paint to Relax” workshop. The three-hour workshop is held in Jan Kok, an 18th century plantation house full of Dutch Caribbean ambience.
“Most people do not realize that painting can also be a great anti-depression and anti-loneliness remedy,” said Sanchez. “You do not need to know how to draw a line; you just need the desire to want to paint and to relax. The rest comes easy.”
Sanchez suggests 30 + as the ideal age for participants. The workshop session concentrates on painting with acrylics and includes all materials: paper, acrylic paint, brushes, and easel. For more information, email Nena Sanchez at info@jankokcuracao.com.
